de.dfki.lt.hfc

Class TIntArrayHashingStrategy

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.dfki.lt.hfc.TIntArrayHashingStrategy

  • public final class TIntArrayHashingStrategy
extends java.lang.Object
    implements a specific hashing and equals strategy for int[] that are used to represent tuples in the tuple store, the rule store, and the forward chainer; NOTE: the positions array must always be SORTED in ascending order to guarantee compatible hash codes!!!
    Since:
    JDK 1.5

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected int[] positions
      when assigned the null value, all positions of the int array(s) are employed in the execution of computeHashCode() and equals(); when assigned an int array, only the values of the array, interpreted as positions, are used in computeHashCode() and equals(); NOTE: this.positions must always be sorted in ascending order to guarantee compatible hash codes!!!

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      TIntArrayHashingStrategy()
      assigns the null value to this.positions
      TIntArrayHashingStrategy(int[] positions)
      should be used during initialization, given an int array of positions

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int computeHashCode(int[] array)
      I borrowed this code from Sun's string implementation for hashCode(); the hash code of tuple t of length n is computed as t[0]*31^(n-1) + t[1]*31^(n-2) + ...
      boolean equals(int[] array1, int[] array2)
      two tuples are equal iff they are pairwise equal, using == on ints; I do not check whether array1 or array2 equals the null value; note further that I do not check whether this.position[this.position.length - 1] < array{1|2}.length note: true is returned in case this.positions equals empty int array

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Field Detail

      • positions

        protected int[] positions
        when assigned the null value, all positions of the int array(s) are employed in the execution of computeHashCode() and equals(); when assigned an int array, only the values of the array, interpreted as positions, are used in computeHashCode() and equals(); NOTE: this.positions must always be sorted in ascending order to guarantee compatible hash codes!!!

    • Constructor Detail

        public TIntArrayHashingStrategy(int[] positions)

    • Method Detail

      • computeHashCode

        public int computeHashCode(int[] array)
        I borrowed this code from Sun's string implementation for hashCode(); the hash code of tuple t of length n is computed as t[0]*31^(n-1) + t[1]*31^(n-2) + ... + t[n-1] using integer ring arithmetic; note that I do not check whether array == null; note further that I do not check whether this.positions[this.positions.length - 1] < array.length note: 1 is returned in case this.positions equals empty int array

      • equals

        public boolean equals(int[] array1,
             int[] array2)
        two tuples are equal iff they are pairwise equal, using == on ints; I do not check whether array1 or array2 equals the null value; note further that I do not check whether this.position[this.position.length - 1] < array{1|2}.length note: true is returned in case this.positions equals empty int array
